posts.name: Dave
posts.cooked: As this season has evolved, our design subteam has been gaining experience and tackling challenges related to advanced building and design techniques. A key obstacle encountered involves the concept of "pocketing material." Given our proximity to the annual weight limit, which has notably increased this year, we decided to conduct research into pocketing techniques in hopes of addressing this issue. However, manual attempts to shape the pockets consistently result in insufficient strength or fail to provide satisfactory weight savings. Additionally, we remain uncertain about the specific programs utilized by higher-level teams, though we suspect an automated tool may be involved. Any further insights would be highly appreciated.

posts.name: Arshon Bozorgi
posts.cooked: Lightning Featurescript is available in Onshape under Julia’s Featurescripts. This has been effective for our team this season, though it does not automatically generate a lightning pattern. Material positioning needs to be manually defined. visit our website FRCDesign.org for more information.

Optimize weight through structural efficiency by removing non-structural material from the outside of plates. Beams often provide more strength per unit weight than plates, particularly when bending forces are involved. To achieve this, consider converting bending loads into tension or compression.

To maximize efficiency, connect points of interest directly, such as screw and bearing holes. Use large radii to avoid small radii, which create stress concentrations and limit tooling options. Boxubes should only be pocketed under specific conditions, which are uncommon in FRC competitions.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: 973 RAMP - Pocketing is a video on YouTube with ID wGmsnD0KQMs.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Pocketed tubes are universal in larger sizes used for telescoping arms, for example (2910, 233, etc). How should teams decide when pocketed tubes are appropriate?

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: What I've been taught is not to pocket tubes unless absolutely necessary. Additionally, I've been informed that pocketed 1/8-inch tubing is actually weaker compared to its 1/16-inch counterpart without pockets.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: A quote states that pocketed 1/8-inch material is weaker than unpocketed 1/16-inch material. This observation raises questions due to the variability in definitions and factors such as pattern density and load direction affecting the strength of pocketed materials.

This is a pretty broad statement. “Pocketing” is not one universal thing; both the type and density of the pattern affect the strength, as does the load direction. Yet it is mostly true. The word that is missing is “weight-normalized.” Any pocketing adds stress risers, which significantly increase the stress experienced by a beam. For reference, a hole on an infinite plane in tension increases the local stress by 3x. The stress risers created by pocketing are worse than a hole on an infinite plane because a boxtube is far from infinite and has localized behaviors that are problematic.

Since 1/8th tube isn’t even 2x as strong as 1/16th tube, adding any stress riser makes you closer to or weaker than the 1/16th tube, while still being about double the weight. There is a way to pocket boxtube without weakening it, but it doesn’t remove very much material—maybe like 10 or 20% at best—in which case the 1/16th tube still is more weight-efficient.

I’m interested in more detail about your last point. Pocketed tubes are universal in larger sizes used for telescoping arms, like the 2910, 233, etc. How should teams decide when pocketed tubes are appropriate?

TL:DR Never in practice unless you don’t care about strength at all.

Consider a cantilever boxtube under uniaxial bending. The stress increases as you approach the support, so you can pocket the far end of the boxtube to avoid increasing stress on the spots that matter. FEA can determine how far away the slots need to be from the support.

Now consider the beam profile. If you pocket the sides of the boxtube, you divide the single large beam with a good second moment of area into two beams with very bad second moment areas. This loss is significant, possibly an order of magnitude or more in strength. So pocketing the sides—even a little—is very bad.

The best pattern to use are large radius holes or slots because they have a large radius, reducing stress concentrations. Triangular patterns are bad because they have sharper corners, creating worse stress risers, making them the weakest point of the beam, even if they’re far from the supports.

But notice how I’ve always said uniaxial bending. The slots on the top/bottom pattern are equivalent to splitting the beam for as long as possible when loaded sideways, which is very bad. In FRC, you rarely get to pick how your robot gets impacted—it’s often determined by drivers or autos, and opponents can cause damage regardless of red cards preventing physical contact. Except for well-designed climbers, there are no safe mechanisms to control the loading direction, making all pocketing effectively bad.

2910 and 1323 got away with pocketing boxtube this year because defense was ineffective, meaning they didn’t care about structural strength—they just needed enough material to mount with minimal weight.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: We skeletonized all of the 1/8" and 1/16" 1x2 tube on our elevator with no issues. It saved us approximately 8 pounds.

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: I would appreciate it if you could share the rib and wall thickness you used, along with the weight of your end effector, for reference during this project.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: The fact that you had no issues with it means you could have gone even lighter with non-pocketed tubing. If you had success with the 1/16th pocketed version, you could easily run a 0.040-inch wall tube (someone in the FIRST Robotics Competition sphere was selling these tubes). Even just shaving down the walls yourself gives a stronger end product. If you have any 1/8-inch wall in your elevator, you should consider using 1/16-inch tubing and just put a hole in it. Every year, I walk the pits and tell teams that you can get away with much thinner wall tubing 90% of the time with a little planning.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
Extraordinary amount of pocketing occurred. 1 x 2 x 0.125" tube weighs 0.067 lb/inch, whereas 1 x 2 x 0.063" tube weighs 0.0354 lb/inch.

Examining your machine, it appears to have 3 tubes per side, each approximately 36", along with a carriage and crossbars totaling roughly 72". Utilizing thin-walled tubes would result in a weight of just 10 pounds prior to pocketing—this level of pocketing seems excessively heavy-handed.

In contrast, thicker-wall tubes weigh around 19 pounds collectively, necessitating significant pocketing to achieve equivalent thin-wall weight.

Most individuals concur that pocketing tubing isn't advisable unless absolutely necessary for increased weight capacity. Thinner walls offer better strength with reduced strain.

Has somebody actually verified how thin you can reasonably go? There comes a point where the walls get so thin that the primary failure mode becomes localized buckling of the sides instead of yielding via flexural stress. We see thin round tube all the time because round tube resists buckling, but I haven’t encountered its use with .4 tubing except at MaxTube, which is problematic due to other issues.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: Our team's goal is to improve customer satisfaction. In order to achieve this, we are focusing on enhancing our product quality and providing better customer support. Additionally, we have set a target to increase our sales by 20% next quarter.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: Desperation is the mother of invention...

RoboChair mentioned that someone in the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) sphere was selling 040 tubes. MAXTube light has 1mm walls but also has the unusual MAXTube profile. REV Robotics designs, builds, and manufactures robotics parts used in STEM education, including components for the FIRST Robotics Competition and FIRST Tech... The product is priced at USD 4.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I would recommend 2471’s Part Lighten Featurescript. It offers more control over everything than Julia’s Lighten. If you want to use large patterns, I would suggest using the cheeseit! Featurescript to create ribs, then use the Part Lighten to actually lighten it.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
I generally agree with your main point about tubes, which I think is that it’s always better to increase radius and decrease wall thickness, until the “panel stiffness” of the tube becomes the limiting factor. Beam stiffness goes as the cube of radius, and mass is only linear.  

I suspect one reason we see so many small pocketed tubes in FIRST Robotics Competition is that there aren’t good templates for resolving point loads, like “lugs” or “hard points” in a space frame. My own team made some nice light arm tubes a couple of years ago, but the joints exhibited buckling and deformation. It’s easier to overgauge the tube, and drill a hole in it, than to engineer a fancy bracket with a socket. Do you know of good examples we might be able to use for teaching about thinner, bigger tubes with better brackets?

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
We ran the .040-inch-thick wall REV 2x1 Maxtube on the fixed and moving stages of our elevator this year. The thin tubes were sufficiently strong and did not exhibit localized deformation, with the elevator bearings experiencing loads equivalent to 122 matches annually.

We employed carbon fiber sheets to enhance the stiffness of the .040-inch-thick tubing. Specifically, we added 1/16-inch carbon fiber sheets to the 1-inch face of the fixed elevator rails. These sheets were bonded using epoxy resin to prevent slippage and riveted to the tubing. The sheets were strategically placed in a stair-step configuration to minimize weight while maximizing the structural contribution of the carbon fiber.

Adding 3/8 of a pound of carbon fiber and rivets enabled us to achieve a deflection comparable to that of .080-inch-thick tubing, approximately .015 inches. This improvement significantly enhanced the system's performance.

Below is a photo of the measurement setup:  
[Photo omitted]

If REV's shipping practices render approximately 20% of the tubing unusable for elevators, many of the received tubes exhibited significant damage, either bending across their entire length or being crushed at the ends due to the absence of packing material. Despite this, we found the REV tubing satisfactory for our robot applications, as using thicker tubing would have made us overweight.

data.title: How to pocket aluminum panels the right way
